Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on Thoracic Drainage Strategies in Lung Cancer Surgery

Background: This study aimed to assess the effectiveness of different thoracic drainage strategies following lung cancer surgery, focusing on digital versus analogue drainage systems and suction versus water seal.

Methods: Conducted at a tertiary care hospital, this randomised controlled trial included patients aged 18-75 undergoing lung cancer surgery, with no prior thoracic surgery. A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the digital drainage system group and 100 to the analogue drainage system group. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes. Due to the nature of the intervention, blinding was not feasible.

Intervention: The intervention group received digital drainage systems, while the control group received analogue systems. The primary outcome was drainage duration, measured over a 30-day postoperative period. Secondary outcomes included length of hospital stay and patient-reported discomfort.

Results: In the intention-to-treat analysis, 98 participants in the digital group and 97 in the analogue group were analysed. The digital group had a significantly shorter drainage duration (mean difference = 1.5 days, 95% CI 0.8 to 2.2; p = 0.001) and reduced hospital stay (mean difference = 2.0 days, 95% CI 1.1 to 2.9; p = 0.002). Patient-reported discomfort was lower in the digital group. Adverse events were reported in 3% of the digital group and 1% of the analogue group, with mild severity.

Interpretation: Digital drainage systems reduced drainage duration and hospital stay compared to analogue systems, suggesting a potential benefit in postoperative care. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and explore patient-specific strategies.

Trial registration: NCT12345678

Funding: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
